question: [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: new()] [Named Address Injection] Can an attacker inject malicious named addresses through build_options.additional_named_addresses that override critical system addresses, causing transactions to be sent to attacker-controlled accounts instead of legitimate framework addresses? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: new()] [Resource Exhaustion] Can an attacker provide a malicious SourceManifest with deeply nested or circular dependencies that cause unbounded recursion during graph initialization, leading to stack overflow and validator node crashes? (High)

(High)

(High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: new()] [Race Condition] Since ResolvingNamedAddress wraps values in Rc<RefCell<>>, can concurrent calls to new() from multiple threads cause race conditions when initializing the global_named_address_pool, leading to inconsistent address resolution across packages? (Medium)

(Critical)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: build_resolution_graph()] [Cycle Detection Bypass] The function checks if source_package == package for early return, but can an attacker craft two packages with identical SourceManifest fields but different underlying code that passes equality check but introduces malicious dependencies? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: build_resolution_graph()] [Address Pool Poisoning] When additional_named_addresses are cloned from build_options, can an attacker modify these addresses after graph initialization but before resolution completes, causing resolved packages to use different addresses than expected? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: build_resolution_graph()] [Dev Mode Privilege Escalation] When build_options.dev_mode is true, dev_dependencies are included - can an attacker inject malicious dev dependencies in production builds by manipulating the dev_mode flag, introducing vulnerable code paths? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: build_resolution_graph()] [Recursive Dependency Bomb] When iterating through dependencies.chain(additional_deps), can an attacker create a dependency tree with exponential expansion where each package depends on N packages, causing O(N^depth) resolution time and DoS? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: process_dependency()] [Address Substitution] The code bails if dep.subst.is_some(), but can an attacker craft a Dependency struct where subst appears None during this check but becomes Some() later due to interior mutability, bypassing this protection?
